Description: Limestone relief fragment of a battle scene with defeated Asians: the fragment was part of a large composition depicting the siege of a walled Near Eastern city. The edge of the Egyptian siege ladder can be seen along the right edge of this fragment. The men fall from the ramparts to their death, pierced with Egyptian arrows. The skin of the foreigners is painted yellow, primarily to indicate that they were lighter complexioned than the Egyptians. The red hair on the head of the figure falling feet downward also indicates a people fairer in both hair and skin than most Egyptians. The painted designs on the kilts are very faded, but we can still see their variety.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr Harry Reginald Holland Hall
Curator's comments: In this early example, the details may well be based on reality, whether actual observation or descriptions by returning soldiers. But with the passage of time, and especially in the New Kingdom, such foreign characteristics tended to become stereotyped. Bibliography: E. Naville and H.R. Hall, The Temple of Deir el-Bahari, 1907, MEEF 28, pl. 14D; W. S. Smith, 'Interconnections in the Ancient Near East' (New Haven & London, 1965), pp. 148-49, fig. 185; (See also EA 733) W. V. Davies, 'British Museum: Catalogue of Egyptian antiquities in the British Museum Vol.7, Tools and weapons 1, Axes' (London, 1987), pl. 37, fig. 2; G. Robins, ‘The Art of Ancient Egypt’ (London, 1997), p. 95, fig. 95 (upside down); B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' II (Oxford, 1974), p. 383; 'Temples and Tombs' [exhibition catalogue] (American Federation of Arts, 2006): 43, cat no. 2. D. Arnold, in A. Oppenheim, D. Arnold, D. Arnold & K. Yamamoto (eds), Ancient Egypt Transformed. The Middle Kingdom, New York 2015, 164-6
Bibliographic references: Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (17)
